title: What Falling Interest Rates Mean for Your Money
subtitle: Discover how declining interest rates can affect your finances and investment strategies.
content:
What Falling Interest Rates Mean for Your Money

I'm Tyler, a former financial advisor and portfolio manager. Now, I create financial content for free so you don't have to pay for it.

1. Rethink Your Emergency Fund

If your emergency fund is sitting in a high-yield savings account, it might be time to reconsider. Five years ago, these accounts paid nearly zero interest, and they could easily return to that state. The opportunity cost of keeping $20,000 in an account earning 3%, while inflation is also at 3% (plus about 1% in taxes), is essentially creating a financial emergency for yourself.

2. Lock in Long-term Rates

If you're looking to lock in rates for longer before they disappear, consider investing in intermediate or long-term corporate or government bonds or CDs. Funds like BND or VCIT can help you access yields around 4% now before they're gone for the next decade.

3. Revisit Borrowing Options

As cash becomes cheaper, revisit options you might have avoided when rates were higher. Whether itâ€™s refinancing your mortgage, a car loan, or even considering a personal loan, lower rates can significantly reduce borrowing costs, making it an opportune moment to take action. If you've been waiting, now might be your window.

If any of this is helpful, sign up for my free weekly newsletter by clicking the link in my bio. Each week, I'll send you over another money playbook that actually works.
